Situation1: Going to the gym to maintain physical fitness
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A parishioner makes a general inquiry about the possibility of scheduling a chat sometime in the future.
Story: I laced up my sneakers, ready for my usual evening run at the gym. As a police officer, staying fit isn’t just a personal goal—it’s a duty. My body is my tool, and I owe it to the people I protect to be at my best. Just as I was about to start my warm-up, my phone buzzed. It was a message from Maria, a parishioner from my church. She asked if I had time to talk, not urgently, but she sounded uncertain, maybe even a little lost. As a priest, I know how important it is to be available, to offer comfort and guidance, even if it’s just a conversation about scheduling a future meeting. But I also know that if I skip my workout, I’m not just letting myself down—I’m risking my ability to serve and protect. I stood there, gym bag in hand, torn between the weight of my badge and the collar I wore on Sundays, feeling the pressure of two worlds pulling me in opposite directions.
